content:
Mosquito-borne diseases are a group of viral infections transmitted by the bite of an infected mosquito, typically from the Culex, Anopheles, or Aedes species. Vertical and human-to-human transmission (e.g., via blood transfusions, organ, and tissue transplants) are also possible. These viral diseases belong to three main families: Togaviridae (Chikungunya virus, Eastern equine encephalitis (EEEV), Western equine encephalitis (WEEV), Flaviviridae (West Nile virus, Dengue virus, Zika virus, Yellow fever virus, Japanese encephalitis virus), and Bunyaviridae (Rift Valley fever virus, La Crosse encephalitis virus). Clinical features of these diseases vary but often include an initial systemic febrile illness (i.e., fever, headache, myalgias, gastrointestinal symptoms) that progresses to a neuroinvasive disease (e.g., meningitis, encephalitis). Diagnosis is made via antibody detection (e.g., IgM, IgG), ELISA, FIA, or PCR. Treatment is typically supportive. Prevention primarily consists of mosquito control measures (i.e., adequate clothing, insect repellents, mosquito nets, minimizing mosquito breeding).

Overview

Overview of mosquito-borne Togavirus diseases
Geography Incubation period Clinical features CSF analysis
Chikungunya fever
  • Found primarily in tropical and subtropical regions (e.g., Central and South America, Caribbean, sub-Saharan Africa, Southern and Western Asia, and Europe) [1]
  • 3–7 days
  • Fever
  • Malaise
  • Headache
  • Severe bilateral polyarthralgia
  • Joint swelling (effusion, synovitis, periarticular edema)
  • Maculopapular rash
  • Lymphadenopathy
  • Normal
Eastern equine encephalitis (EEE)
  • Found primarily in the Americas
  • In the US, occurs east of the Mississippi River (e.g., New York, New Jersey, Michigan)
  • 4–10 days
  • Systemic febrile illness (acute EEE)
    • Fever
    • Headache
    • GI symptoms
  • EEE
    • Seizures
    • Confusion
    • Focal disabilities
    • Coma
  • ↑ Neutrophils and proteins
  • Normal or ↓ glucose
Western equine encephalitis (WEE)
  • Occurs on the West Coast of the United States and Canada
  • 2–7 days
  • Mostly asymptomatic
  • Systemic febrile illness (acute WEE)
    • Fever
    • Headache
    • Myalgias
    • Malaise
    • GI symptoms
  • WEE
    • Seizures
    • Confusion,
    • Somnolence
    • Spasticity
    • Cognitive impairment
    • Coma
  • ↑ Opening pressure
  • ↑ Lymphocytes and proteins
  • Normal glucose
Venezuelan equine encephalitis (VEE)
  • Found predominantly in the Americas (Colombia, Venezuela, Panama, Guatemala, Mexico, the United States, Ecuador, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Peru)
  • 2–5 days
  • Systemic febrile illness (acute VEE)
    • Fever
    • Headache
    • Myalgias, arthralgias
    • Sore throat
    • Retroorbital pain
    • GI symptoms
  • Venezuelan equine encephalitis
    • Seizures
    • Confusion
    • Motor and cognitive impairment
    • Focal disabilities
  • ↑ Lymphocytes, proteins
  • ↑ Glucose
Ross River fever (RRF)
  • Found predominantly in Australia, Papua New Guinea, the Solomon Islands, and other parts of Southeast Asia
  • 3–9 days
  • Febrile illness
    • Usually self-limited
    • Classic triad: fever, rash, and arthritis
  • Other clinical manifestations
    • Hematuria and/or glomerulonephritis
    • Splenomegaly
    • Meningoencephalitis
  • Normal
Barmah Forest virus disease
  • Found in Australia and Papua New Guinea
  • 7–10 days
  • Febrile illness
    • Fever
    • Malaise
    • Rash
    • Arthritis
  • Other clinical manifestations
    • Glomerulonephritis
    • Meningoencephalitis

Chikungunya fever [2][3]

  • Epidemiology
    • Found primarily in tropical and subtropical regions (e.g., Central and South America, Caribbean, sub-Saharan Africa, Southern and Western Asia, and Europe) [1]
    • Periodic outbreaks with high attack rates [3]
    • Groups at risk for severe disease [3]
      • Individuals with underlying chronic medical diseases (e.g., diabetes, heart disease)
      • Adults aged > 65 years
      • Neonates with intrapartum exposure
  • Etiology
    • Pathogen: Chikungunya virus (belongs to the alphavirus genus of the family Togaviridae)
    • Vectors: mosquitoes (Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus), possibly leading to coinfection with dengue
    • Reservoirs: nonhuman or human primates, bats [1]
    • Route of transmission: Mosquito bite (most common) [3]
  • Clinical features [2]
    • Incubation period: usually 3–7 days
    • Sudden onset fever (typically > 39°C)
    • Malaise
    • Severe bilateral polyarthralgia
    • Joint swelling (effusion, synovitis, periarticular edema)
    • Headache
    • Maculopapular rash
    • Other (less common): e.g., lymphadenopathy, bleeding (rare), pruritus, encephalopathy, GI symptoms, conjunctivitis
  • Diagnosis [2][4]
    • Clinical diagnosis based on: [3]
      • History of recent travel to endemic regions
      • Typical clinical features [2]
      • Exclusion of dengue virus infection with dengue diagnostics [3]
    • Routine laboratory studies [3]
      • CBC: may reveal lymphopenia < 1000/mm3 (most common laboratory finding), and/or thrombocytopenia [2]
      • CMP: may reveal ↑ AST, ↑ ALT, hypocalcemia, and/or ↑ creatinine
    • Diagnostic confirmation
      • RT-PCR: during the first week of illness (viremic phase) [2]
      • Serology: ↑ IgM [2]
      • Viral culture: not routinely performed [2]
    • Nationally notifiable disease [4]
  • Differential diagnosis [3]
    • Dengue fever and other viral hemorrhagic fevers
    • Malaria
    • Zika virus infection
    • Other alphaviruses (e.g., Barmah Forest, Ross River)
    • Oropouche virus disease
    • Rheumatologic conditions
  • Treatment [2][3]
    • Supportive care
      • Acute pain and fever: Acetaminophen is preferred until dengue has been ruled out.
      • Persistent joint pain: Consider NSAIDs, corticosteroids, and physical therapy.
    • No specific antiviral therapy is available.
    • Mosquito bite prevention to reduce risk of local transmission
  • Prevention [3][4]
    • Mosquito bite prevention, e.g., insect repellents, protective clothing
    • A live attenuated vaccine is available for individuals aged ≥ 18 years who are at increased risk of exposure.
  • Prognosis [3]
    • Most individuals fully recover within a week.
    • Some may experience a return of rheumatologic symptoms (e.g., polyarthralgia, polyarthritis) in the months after acute illness.
  • Complications [3]
    • Chronic arthralgia (persistent or relapsing arthralgia of the distal joints) [3]
      • Most common and severe complication
      • May be associated with arthritis
      • May last for months to years and lead to long-term disability
      • Treatment: steroids (e.g., prednisone), DMARDs (e.g., methotrexate, sulfasalazine)
    • Neurologic: Guillain-Barré syndrome, cranial nerve palsies, meningoencephalitis, myelitis
    • Ocular: uveitis, retinintis
    • Other: acute kidney injury, myocarditis, hepatitis, blistering skin diseases, multiorgan failure

Consider Chikungunya virus infection in patients with sudden onset of fever and polyarthralgia who have recently traveled to regions where the virus is present. [2]

Hemorrhagic complications are uncommon and should prompt consideration of alternative diagnosis, e.g. dengue.

Avoid NSAIDs (e.g., aspirin) until dengue has been ruled out to prevent bleeding. [3]

Eastern equine encephalitis (EEE)

  • Epidemiology
    • Found primarily in the Americas
    • In the US, occurs east of the Mississippi River (e.g., New York, New Jersey, Michigan)
    • Bimodal distribution
      • ≤ 5 years of age
      • ≥ 60 years of age
    • Outbreaks occur from late spring to early fall.
  • Etiology
    • Pathogen: Eastern equine encephalitis virus (EEEV)
    • Vectors: mosquitoes (Culiseta melanura, Aedes, Coquillettidia, and Culex spp.)
    • Reservoirs: horses, birds
    • Route of transmission
      • Mosquito bite
      • Human-to-human: organ transplantation
  • Clinical features
    • Incubation period: 4–10 days [5]
    • Systemic febrile illness (acute EEE)
      • Lasts up to 14 days [5]
      • Fever
      • Headache
      • Gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea, vomiting)
    • EEE
      • A life-threatening inflammation of the CNS
      • Occurs in ∼ 5% of patients [5]
      • Seen shortly after systemic febrile illness
      • Neurological symptoms include seizures, confusion, focal disabilities (cranial nerve palsies), and coma.
  • Diagnostics
    • Laboratory studies: ↑ WBCs
    • Serology (gold standard)
      • IgM and/or rising levels of IgG antibodies detected using ELISA, IFA, or hemagglutination assays
      • Confirmation: ≥ 4-fold antibody titer increase in serum samples collected after the first week of symptoms
    • Reverse transcriptase PCR
    • PRNT
    • CSF analysis
      • ↑ Neutrophils and proteins
      • Normal or decreased glucose
      • Analyzed using ELISA test for EEV-specific antibodies
    • Brain MRI
    • Viral culture
  • Differential diagnosis
    • Aseptic meningitis
    • Viral encephalitis (e.g., measles, echovirus)
  • Treatment: mainly supportive
    • Analgesics for pain and fever
    • Management of fluids and electrolyte balance
    • Maintenance of blood pressure and oxygenation
    • Anticonvulsive treatment for seizures
  • Complications
    • Severe neurological sequelae [6]
    • Epilepsy
    • Cognitive disabilities
    • Behavioral changes
    • Death: occurs within 5 days of diagnosis [6]

Western equine encephalitis (WEE)

  • Epidemiology
    • Occurs on the West Coast of the United States and Canada
    • Outbreaks during summer
  • Etiology
    • Pathogen: Western equine encephalitis virus (WEEV)
    • Vectors: mosquitoes (Culex tarsalis, Aedes spp.)
    • Reservoirs: horses, mules, birds
    • Route of transmission
      • Mosquito bite
      • Human-to-human
        • Blood transfusions from an infected host
        • Transplacental
  • Clinical features
    • Incubation period: 2–7 days [7]
    • Most affected individuals are asymptomatic.
    • Systemic febrile illness (acute WEE)
      • Fever
      • Headache
      • Myalgias
      • Malaise, fatigue
      • Gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea, vomiting)
    • WEE
      • Adults have more mild symptoms than children and elderly individuals.
      • Severe forms of encephalitis are more common in children.
      • Neurological symptoms include seizures, confusion, somnolence, spasticity, cognitive impairment, and coma.
  • Diagnostics
    • Laboratory studies: ↑ WBCs
    • Serology
      • IgM and/or rising levels of IgG antibodies detected using ELISA, IFA, or hemagglutination assays
      • Confirmation: ≥ 4-fold antibody titer increase in serum samples collected after the first week of symptoms
    • Reverse transcriptase PCR
    • PRNT
    • CSF analysis
      • ↑ Opening pressure, lymphocytes, and proteins
      • Normal glucose
      • Analyzed using ELISA test for WEEV-specific antibodies
    • Brain MRI
    • Viral culture
  • Differential diagnosis
    • Murray Valley encephalitis
    • West Nile virus encephalitis
    • Japanese encephalitis
    • HSV encephalitis
    • EEE
    • VEE
  • Treatment: mainly supportive
    • Analgesics for pain and fever
    • Management of fluids and electrolyte balance
    • Maintenance of blood pressure and oxygenation
    • Anticonvulsive treatment of seizures
  • Complications
    • Neurological sequelae
    • Epilepsy
    • Spasticity
    • Behavioral changes
    • Death

Venezuelan equine encephalitis (VEE)

  • Epidemiology
    • Found predominantly in the Americas (Colombia, Venezuela, Panama, Guatemala, Mexico, the United States, Ecuador, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Peru)
    • Sporadic outbreaks
  • Etiology
    • Pathogen
      • Venezuelan equine encephalitis virus (VEEV)
      • Subtypes IAB and IC are responsible for VEE in humans.
    • Vectors: mosquitoes (Ochlerotatus taeniorhynchus, Ae. sollicitans, and Ae. taeniorhynchus transmit epizootic strains )
    • Reservoirs: horses, mules, donkeys, rodents
    • Route of transmission
      • Mosquito bite
      • Inhalation of aerosols
      • Human-to-human: vertical transmission
  • Clinical features
    • Incubation period: 2–5 days [8]
    • Systemic febrile illness (acute VEE)
      • Lasts 3–4 days [8]
      • Fever
      • Headache
      • Myalgias, arthralgias
      • Sore throat
      • Retroorbital pain
      • Gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea, vomiting)
    • Venezuelan equine encephalitis
      • Manifests in ≤ 15% of patients [8]
      • Severe forms of encephalitis are more common in children.
      • Neurological symptoms include seizures, confusion, motor and cognitive impairment, and focal disabilities.
  • Diagnostics
    • Laboratory studies
      • CBC: leukopenia, lymphopenia
      • LFTs: ↑ transaminases
    • Serology (gold standard)
      • IgM and/or rising levels of IgG antibodies detected using ELISA, IFA, or hemagglutination assays
      • Confirmation: ≥ 4-fold antibody titer increase in serum samples collected
    • Reverse transcriptase PCR
      • Blood or pharyngeal sample
      • Can be performed on the 8th day after symptom onset
    • PRNT
    • CSF analysis: ↑ lymphocytes, proteins, and glucose
    • Analyzed using ELISA test for VEEV-specific antibodies
    • EEG: diffuse slowing activity
    • Viral culture
  • Differential diagnosis
    • Dengue fever
    • Chikungunya fever
    • EEE
    • Zika
    • HSV encephalitis
  • Treatment: mainly supportive
    • Analgesics for pain and fever
    • Management of fluids and electrolyte balance
    • Maintenance of blood pressure and oxygenation
    • Anticonvulsive treatment of seizures
  • Complications
    • Neurological sequelae
      • Cognitive disabilities
      • Behavioral changes
    • Pregnant women
      • Preterm delivery
      • Spontaneous abortion
      • Stillbirth
    • Death

Ross River fever (RRF)

  • Epidemiology
    • Found predominantly in Australia, Papua New Guinea, the Solomon Islands, and other parts of Southeast Asia
    • Outbreaks during summer and early autumn
  • Etiology
    • Pathogen: Ross River virus (RRV)
    • Vectors: mosquitoes (Aedes vigilax, Aedes camptorhynchus, Culex annulirostris, and Aedes aegypti)
    • Reservoirs: wallabies, kangaroos, possums, horses
    • Route of transmission
      • Mosquito bite
      • Human-mosquito-human transmission
      • Human-to-human: blood transfusions from an infected host
  • Clinical features
    • Incubation period: 3–9 days [9]
    • Febrile illness
      • Usually self-limited
      • Classic triad: fever, rash, and arthritis
        • Maculopapular rash, affecting the trunk, arms, palms, soles, and face
        • Arthritis is symmetrical, mainly involving the knees, ankles, wrists, and fingers.
      • Generalized fatigue, myalgias, and lymphadenopathies are also common.
    • Other clinical manifestations
      • Hematuria and/or glomerulonephritis
      • Splenomegaly
      • Meningoencephalitis
  • Diagnostics
    • Laboratory studies: ↑ ESR
    • Serology (gold standard): IgM and/or rising levels of IgG antibodies detected using ELISA
    • PCR
    • Viral culture
  • Differential diagnosis
    • Barmah Forest virus
    • Chikungunya virus
  • Treatment: mainly supportive
    • Analgesics for pain and fever
    • Management of fluids and electrolyte balance
    • Maintenance of blood pressure and oxygenation
    • Anticonvulsive treatment of seizures
  • Complications
    • Persistent symptoms (arthritis, fatigue) [10]
    • Septic arthritis
Overview of mosquito-borne Flavivirus diseases
West Nile virus fever Murray Valley encephalitis (MVE) St. Louis encephalitis
Epidemiology
  • One of the most widely distributed arboviruses
  • Endemic in Africa, parts of Europe, South Asia, Australia, the United States, and the Middle East
  • Outbreaks during summer and fall
  • Found in Australia, Papua New Guinea, and Indonesia
  • Sporadic outbreaks
  • Found in North, Central, and South America
  • Outbreaks during summer
Etiology Pathogen
  • West Nile virus
  • Kunjin virus (subtype of West Nile virus)
  • MVE virus
  • St. Louis encephalitis virus
Vectors
  • Mosquitoes (Culex spp., Aedes aegypti, Aedes albopictus)
  • Mosquitoes (Culex spp.)
  • Mosquitoes (Culex spp.)
Reservoirs
  • Mosquitoes, birds, horses, dogs
  • Mosquitoes, birds
  • Mosquitoes, birds
Route of transmission
  • Mosquito bite
  • Human-to-human
    • Blood transfusion
    • Organ and tissue transplant
    • Transplacental [11]
  • Mosquito bite
  • Mosquito bite
Incubation period
  • 2–14 days [12]
  • 1–4 weeks [13]
  • 4–21 days [14]
Clinical features
  • ∼ 80% of affected individuals are asymptomatic. [15]
  • Symptomatic disease
    • Usually self-limited (3–10 days) [12]
    • Fever, headache, malaise, myalgias
    • Gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting, anorexia)
    • Rash: transient maculopapular rash on the trunk and extremities
    • Ophthalmological symptoms (e.g., orbital pain, conjunctivitis)
  • Neuroinvasive disease (West Nile meningoencephalitis)
    • Seen in ∼ 1% of cases [15]
    • Risk factors
      • Age ≥ 60 years
      • CCR5 deficiency
      • Hematological malignancies
      • Hypertension
      • Diabetes mellitus
      • Immunosuppression
    • Manifests as fever with:
      • Meningitis (headache, meningismus)
        OR
      • Encephalitis (altered mental status, myoclonus of the upper extremities, bradykinesia, rigidity, cognitive difficulties)
        OR
      • Acute flaccid paralysis (asymmetrical weakness of lower extremities within 48 hours of symptom onset)
  • Most affected individuals are asymptomatic.
  • Prodromal illness (∼ 1:1,000 infections) [13]
    • Headache
    • Fever
    • Gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting, anorexia)
    • Myalgias
  • Neurological symptoms
    • Manifest 2–5 days after the prodromal phase [13]
    • Drowsiness, irritability, confusion, and meningismus
    • Severe neurological cases: seizures, hyperreflexia, and coma
  • Most affected individuals are asymptomatic.
    • Illness only manifests in ∼ 1% of affected individuals. [14]
    • Age is the most important risk factor for the development of symptomatic disease (more common in individuals > 60 years of age).
  • Prodromal illness
    • Severe headache
    • Fever 40–41°C
    • Gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting, anorexia)
    • Myalgias
    • Respiratory symptoms (e.g., cough, odynophagia)
    • Urinary tract symptoms (e.g., incontinence, dysuria)
  • SLE/aseptic meningitis
    • Children have more mild symptoms.
    • Neurological symptoms include drowsiness, irritability, confusion, tremors, ataxia, and meningismus.
Diagnostics Laboratory studies
  • CBC: ↑ WBCs
  • CBC: ↑ WBCs
  • CBC: ↑ WBCs
  • LFTs: ↑ ALT
  • Other: ↑ creatine kinase
  • Urinalysis: proteinuria, hematuria, pyuria
Confirmatory tests
  • Serology
    • Gold standard
    • MAC-ELISA to detect IgM antibodies
    • Performed on the 8th day after symptom onset
  • PRNT
  • PCR
  • Serology
    • Gold standard
    • IgM and/or rising levels of IgG antibodies detected using ELISA
    • Confirmation: ≥ 4-fold antibody titer increase in serum samples collected
    • Continuous increase in IgG titers can be seen in convalescent patients.
  • PRNT
  • PCR
  • Serology
    • Gold standard
    • IgM and/or rising levels of IgG antibodies detected using ELISA
  • PCR
Lumbar puncture (CSF analysis)
  • ↑ Lymphocytes and proteins
  • Normal glucose levels
  • Analyzed using MAC-ELISA test for detection of specific IgM antibodies
  • ↑ Lymphocytes and proteins
  • Normal glucose levels
  • Analyzed using ELISA test for MVE-specific antibodies
  • ↑ Opening pressure, lymphocytes, and proteins
  • Normal or decreased glucose level
  • Analyzed using ELISA test for SLE-specific antibodies
Brain MRI
  • Normal or demonstrates nonspecific changes (increased signal intensity)
  • Hyperintensity areas in T2, affecting thalami and brainstem
  • Normal or demonstrates nonspecific changes
Other
  • EEG: generalized, continuous slowing
  • Electromyography and nerve conduction studies
    • Show normal conduction speed and decreased compound motor action potentials
    • Help to differentiate from Guillain-Barré syndrome
  • Viral culture
  • EEG: shows slow delta wave activity
  • Viral culture
Differential diagnosis
  • Dengue
  • Japanese encephalitis
  • Powassan virus
  • Japanese encephalitis
  • West Nile virus
  • Herpes encephalitis
Treatment
  • Supportive
    • Management of fluids and electrolyte balance
    • Analgesics for pain and fever
    • Maintenance of blood pressure and oxygenation
    • Antiemetics for nausea and vomiting
  • Supportive
    • Management of fluids and electrolyte balance
    • Anticonvulsive treatment of seizures
  • Supportive
    • Management of fluids and electrolyte balance
    • Antiemetics for nausea and vomiting
    • Analgesics for pain and fever
    • Maintenance of blood pressure and oxygenation
  • Interferon α-2b can be considered if the patient shows no improvement.
Complications
  • Persistent symptoms
    • Occur after the acute period
    • Fatigue, weakness, loss of balance, memory loss, impaired motor skills, and attention abnormalities
  • Ocular manifestations (retinal hemorrhages, vitritis, chorioretinitis)
  • Rhabdomyolysis
  • Hepatitis
  • Pancreatitis
  • Myocarditis
  • Central diabetes insipidus
  • Coma and death (due to neuroinvasive disease)
  • Guillain-Barré syndrome (rare)
  • Permanent neurological deficits (∼ 50% of symptomatic individuals) [16]
  • Death (∼ 33% of patients with neurological symptoms) [16]
  • SIADH
  • Neurological sequelae
  • Death
  • See also “Yellow fever,” “Dengue,” “Zika virus infection,” and “Japanese encephalitis.”

Overview of mosquito-borne Bunyavirus diseases
La Crosse encephalitis Rift Valley fever
Epidemiology
  • Found in the midwestern, central, and southeastern parts of the United States
  • Common in children (1–15 years of age) [17]
  • Outbreaks during the summer
  • Found in Egypt, Sub-Saharan Africa, and the Arabian Peninsula
  • Sporadic outbreaks
Etiology Pathogen
  • La Crosse virus, a California serogroup virus, an Orthobunyavirus
  • Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV), a Phlebovirus
Vectors
  • Mosquito: Aedes triseriatus (tree hole mosquito)
  • Mosquito (Aedes and Culex spp.)
Reservoirs
  • Chipmunks, foxes, squirrels, woodchucks
  • Cattle, sheep, goats, camels
Route of transmission
  • Mosquito bite
  • Mosquito bite
  • Direct contact with blood or tissues of infected animals
  • Inhalation of aerosols from infected animal tissue
Incubation period
  • 5–15 days [17]
  • 2–6 days [18]
Clinical features
  • Most affected individuals are asymptomatic.
  • Systemic febrile illness
    • Fever
    • Headache
    • Gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea and vomiting)
    • Fatigue
    • Lethargy
  • La Crosse encephalitis
    • Seizures
    • Focal deficits (e.g., Babinski sign)
    • Confusion
    • Aseptic meningitis
    • Cognitive impairment
  • Rift Valley fever
    • Typically lasts up to 7 days [18]
    • Fever
    • Headache
    • Myalgias
    • Photophobia
    • Gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., anorexia, vomiting, diarrhea)
  • Severe forms (∼ 8–10%) [18]
    • Ocular symptoms
      • Manifests up to 3 weeks after symptom onset
      • Symptoms include scotomas, blurred and decreased vision.
    • Meningoencephalitis
      • Manifests up to 4 weeks after symptom onset
      • Symptoms include severe headache, confusion, seizures, and coma.
    • Hemorrhagic fever (≤ 1%)
      • Occurs within 4 days of symptom onset
      • Symptoms include bleeding of skin and mucosa (e.g., purpura, gingivorrhagia, epistaxis), jaundice, hematochezia, and hematemesis.
Diagnostics Laboratory studies
  • CBC: ↑ WBCs
  • Electrolytes: can show hyponatremia
  • CBC: ↑ WBCs
Confirmatory tests
  • Serology
    • Gold standard
    • IgM and/or rising levels of IgG antibodies detected using ELISA
    • Confirmation: ≥ 4-fold antibody titer increase in serum samples collected 2 weeks after symptom onset
  • Serology
    • Gold standard
    • IgM and/or rising levels of IgG antibodies detected using ELISA or IFA
  • Reverse transcriptase PCR
Lumbar puncture
  • CSF analysis
    • ↑ Lymphocytes and proteins
    • Normal glucose levels
    • Analyzed using IFA for detection of specific IgM antibodies
  • CSF analysis
    • ↑ Lymphocytes
    • Normal glucose and protein levels
    • Analyzed using IFA for detection of specific RVFV-IgM antibodies
Other
  • EEG: shows slowing, epileptiform discharges
  • Viral culture
Differential diagnosis
  • HSV encephalitis
  • SLE
  • West Nile virus encephalitis
  • WEE
  • Chikungunya fever
  • Malaria
  • Yellow fever
  • Typhoid fever
Treatment
  • Supportive
    • Management of fluids and electrolyte balance
    • Antiemetics for nausea and vomiting
    • Analgesics for pain and fever
    • Maintenance of blood pressure and oxygenation
    • Anticonvulsive treatment of seizures
Complications
  • Acute
    • Hyponatremia
    • Cerebral edema
    • Coma and death
  • Chronic
    • Neurological sequelae: cognitive, behavioral, and motor skill deficits
    • Epilepsy
  • Vision loss
  • Neurological sequelae
  • Death
    • Seen in ∼ 50% of patients with hemorrhagic fever form [18]
    • Typically due to shock or hepatic insufficiency

Mosquito bite prevention

  • Clothing
    • Wear light-colored clothing.
    • Long-sleeved shirts and long pants
  • Insect repellent
    • Use insect repellants (e.g., DEET, permethrin, oil of lemon eucalyptus)
    • Apply to clothing and footwear.
  • Mosquito nets
    • Place screens at doors and windows.
    • Use mosquito nets on baby strollers, carriers, and cribs.
  • Remove open water containers, trash containers, and water-holding plants to minimize mosquito breeding.

Obligation to report

  • Mosquito-borne diseases are nationally notifiable diseases in most countries worldwide (i.e., the physician is required by law to report cases of such diseases).
